III. INVESTIGATION
Rule Code Eligibility requirements
Title
Rule Code & CPA Rule 400.12504
Section (1) An agency shall document the rationale for selection of
Description independent living as the most appropriate placement for
the youth.
1

Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation Youth was in an Independent Living Placement and went to the
hospital after experiencing a mental health episode. Youth left the
hospital and was staying in a shelter. Following this, youth was
located by law enforcement wearing minimal clothing. Youth was
then dropped off at the residence of an adult with little items or
medications. There is a concern with the youth's case
management and if the youth is appropriate for IL given their
needs. They were unable to be contacted recently.
Investigation INTERVIEWS
Director was interviewed via video conferencing on 9/24/2024
about concerns that arose about Youth A’s appropriateness for
Independent Living placement after reading a complaint received
by DCWL . Director reported Youth A’s assigned worker at the
time of the complaint, Foster Care Worker, no longer works for the
agency and the current worker does not know Youth A yet;
however, Director is very familiar with Youth A’s case. Director
reported Youth A was referred to the agency by MDHHS staff for
ILP placement and services in November of 2023 after Youth A
successfully completed residential programming. Director stated
Youth A was interviewed for the agency’s ILP program and did
very well , so she was accepted into the program on November
20, 2023. Youth A actively participated in the program and was
successful for three months after which she wanted to live
independently with an identified supportive adult. Director stated
the agency kept case management responsibility because Youth
A was doing so well working with the agency’s case managers
and therapist. Director stated Youth A continued to attend school,
look for employment, take her medications, and participate in
therapy. After a few weeks, Youth A reached out to the ILP house
manager, who is a support to Youth A, and asked if she could
move back in due to a falling out with the adult with whom she
was living. Director stated she and the ILP staff had a meeting
with Youth A to discuss the program rule requirements to which
Youth A agreed. Youth A moved back into the ILP home in July of
2024. After three weeks, Youth A had a friend help her move out
of the ILP home after the staff had left for the day. Director and the
ILP staff met with Youth A who stated she moved out because she
did not want to follow house rules and wanted to live with an adult
she refers to as her aunt, Caregiver. Director stated Foster Care
Worker visited Caregiver’s home and deemed it appropriate for
Youth A. Caregiver agreed to allow Youth A to move in and stated
she was willing to provide support to Youth A, so Youth A moved
into her home as an IL placement at the end of July. Youth A was
2

17 at the time and agreed to attend school and look for a job.
Shortly after, Youth A stopped taking her medication and started
experiencing mental health concerns resulting in her visiting local
emergency rooms. Director stated it has been difficult getting help
for Youth A when she goes to the local hospital as she yells and
spits when she does not get immediate attention resulting in the
hospital staff believing her actions are strictly behavioral, so they
sedate and restrain her rather than addressing her mental health
concerns. Youth A stayed at the hospital for 5-7 days with agency
staff remaining with her 24/7, after which Youth A was discharged
to Caregiver’s home. Youth A would agree to follow up with her
doctor for her medication but ended up back in the emergency
room. Director stated this happened more than once. Director
reported Youth A was continuing to attend school in between her
emergency room visits.
Director stated she didn’t know Youth A was in an emergency
shelter at any point and doesn’t know how that would have come
about unless she went there on her own. After each
hospitalization, Youth A has returned to Caregiver’s home.
Caregiver did tell Director she had tried to call Foster Care Worker
over a weekend when Youth A was brought to her home by the
police, but Foster Care Worker did not answer. Caregiver has
expressed to Director her continued willingness to provide support
to Youth A. Youth A is currently hospitalized, and Caregiver will be
participating in a scheduled Family Team Meeting to discuss
Youth A’s upcoming discharge and return to Caregiver’s home.
Director stated Youth A is turning 18 next week and is adamant
she wants her case closed. She has been provided information
about the Young Adult Voluntary Foster Care program and its
benefits but continues to state she wants her case closed at the
next court hearing scheduled for October 10, 2024.
DOCUMENTS REVIEWED
The following documents were reviewed in Youth A’s case record:
o 11/9/2022 court order documenting Youth A’s goal as
Another Planned Living Arrangement as reunification is not
appropriate
o 11/20/2023 enrollment in alternative education
o 6/21/2024 Case Service Plan Documenting Youth A’s
participation in school, therapy, and summer employment
o 9/12/2024 Case Service Plan in which Youth A’s
participation in life skills classes and school attendance is
documented as well as a recommendation Youth A
continue in Independent Living Placement as reunification
3

is not an option and Youth A does not want to be in a
guardianship or an adoptive placement.
o 8/1/2024 Medical Passport documenting Youth A is current
with her medical care
o After visit summaries from hospital visits for psychiatric
services on 7/8/24, 7/12/24, 7/28/24, 8/2/24, 8/14/24 and
9/4/24
o Youth A’s Placement History
• 11/2023-2/28/2024 ILP
• 2/29/2024-7/1/2024 IL
• 7/1/2024-7/25/2024 ILP
• 7/25/2024-9/16/2024 IL
• 9/16/2024-9/26/2024 Psychiatric Hospital
• 9/26/2024-10/4/2024 IL
• 10/4/2024-current Psychiatric Hospital
Analysis The agency is found in compliance as it is documented in Youth
A’s record, she was actively participating in life skills courses, high
school education, mental health therapy, and was either employed
or seeking employment from November of 2023 until July of 2024
after which Youth A repeatedly sought out psychiatric treatment.
Conclusion Violation Not Established
IV. RECOMMENDATION
Based on investigative findings the facility is in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. It is recommended that the current license status be
continued.
